title: 103_hr3464
content:
The Act titled "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes $15,000,000 for the modernization or replacement of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System used by the United States Forest Service to improve fire fighting response time. SEC. 3. IMPROVEMENT OF FIRE FIGHTING RESPONSE TIME.

The Forest Service, in consultation with local fire chiefs and experts, will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year.

SEC. 4. INCREASED CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR ARSONISTS. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders may face fines or up to 10 years imprisonment, with specific circumstances leading to harsher punishments. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders may face fines or imprisonment based on the extent of damage or harm caused, ranging from 5 to 30 years in prison. If personal injury or damage exceeding $25,000,000 occurs, the offender may face a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. In cases of death, the offender could be fined and imprisoned for over 25 years or face life imprisonment, and may also be subject to the death penalty. The offender may face imprisonment for over 25 years or life imprisonment, and potentially the death penalty for certain offenses related to interstate commerce. The offender may face imprisonment for up to 10 years, or a fine, or both, for certain offenses. If the damage exceeds $1,000,000, the punishment includes a fine and imprisonment for 5 to 20 years. If a person's life is endangered, the offender may face imprisonment for not less than 5 years. If the life of any person is endangered or damage exceeds $10,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 8 to 30 years. If personal injury or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender may be fined and imprisoned for 10 to 40 years. If death results, the offender faces consequences. If death results, the offender shall be fined and imprisoned for any term of years greater than 25 (or imprisonment for life), and may also face the death penalty. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new provision stating that anyone who recklessly engages in conduct prohibited by certain subsections, resulting in destruction of a dwelling or injury to a person, shall face fines, imprisonment up to one year, or both. If not imprisoned, the individual must serve probation with community service hours. The new provision in Title 18, United States Code imposes penalties for reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury. Offenders may face fines, up to one year in prison, or probation with community service hours. Juveniles adjudicated for similar offenses must spend time in a residential institution and perform community service. Whoever negligently engages in conduct that would be prohibited by subsection (f) or (i) of this section shall be fined or imprisoned for up to one month. If not imprisoned, probation with 100-1000 hours of community service is mandatory. Juveniles adjudicated for similar offenses must spend time in a residential institution and perform community service. Juveniles adjudicated for offenses similar to those prohibited by subsection (f) or (i) must spend at least two days in a residential institution and perform 100-1000 hours of community service. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire experts, will study legal barriers to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. Defense conversion will strengthen private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they will explore reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study building roads and backup power for water supply in national forests to enhance fire fighting. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. SEC. 8. REVENUE OFFSET. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
